publisher.orgName: Department of Digital Humanities, University of Graz

authority.orgName: Department of Digital Humanities, University of Graz

seriesStmt.title: GlossIT: Celtic and Latin glossing traditions: uncovering early medieval language contact and knowledge transfer
GlossIT: Keltische und lateinische Glossen als Quellen für frühmittelalterlichen Sprachkontakt und Wissenstransfer

editorialDecl.p: was über die editionsregeln und kodierungsrichtlinien

projectDesc.p: Glosses are fingerprints of the society in which texts were composed, copied, and read. Most importantly, they play a much more significant role than previous research has acknowledged and offer insights about the multilingual and multi-ethnic environment of medieval manuscript and text production the principal texts cannot: they are first-hand testimonies of the close linguistic and cultural connections between Insular Celtic (Old Breton, Old Irish, Old Welsh) and Latin speakers. GLOSSIT researches these contacts combining methods of comparative philology and historical linguistics, digital humanities (handwritten text recognition, network analysis, natural language processing), (cultural) history, and biological computation (applying DNA-sequence alignment methods to glosses).

div.ab: ad huc ĩ cȩlo positus. qm̃o dt̃ ascendã incelũ. Sed quia legimꝰ cælũ cæli dño cũ ee͠t
incȩloid est ĩfirmam̃to. In cælũ ubi soliũ dñi est cupiebat ascendere ñhumili

debemꝰ ĩtelligere.- qui nec p̃cipitatus quiescat; sed ad huc sibi grandia reꝓmittit.

abier̃. Et lux ab oriente medias int̃ undas emergens cunctã suꝑficiẽ t̃rae oꝑuit;
latitudine sui fulgoris boreales simul australesq; nec ñ et occiduas oras atingens.
paulatimq; et sẽ cõpleto diei uns spatio subducens inferia t̃ræ girando subiit.

solis illustraret᷑ atq; ibi ẽet dies; posset enim et aquas illuminare qñ ab eis ñ posset
afflatu quantã libet aquarũ ꝓfunditatem illustrare potuisse. maxime
cũ tenuiores tc̃ aq;- fuisse credant᷑ pus quã eas condit ĩcongregationẽ unã
cogeret ut apparere posset arida. Et diẽ quidẽ uulgarem dñs p̃sentia solis
quã et supͣ posui diffiniuit dicens.- Nonne xii hæ diei st̃. Moyses aut̃ ꝓpͥum
ita descripsit. Et factũ ÷ ĩqṭ uesꝑe &mane dies unꝰ. quẽ ebrei caldei et ꝑsȩ.
sequentes iuxta pͥmae conditionis ordinẽ diei cursũ amane admane deducunt
umbraꝵ uidelicet tẽpus luci supponentes; at contra ægiptu ab oc,asu ad
occasũ; Porroro mani á medio noctis ĩ mediũ; umbri & athinenses ã meridie
ad meridiẽ dies suos cõputare maluer̃. Diuina at̃ auctoritas quȩ ĩ genesidies
ámane usq; admane cõputandos eẽ decreuit.- Eadẽ ĩ euangelio totiꝰ diei tẽpꝰ
á uesꝑa ĩchoari & consumari sanx,it ĩuesꝑã. Quia qui ĩ exdio mundi pͥus lucẽ
uocauit diẽ deĩde tenebras noctẽ. Ipse infine scłoꝝ pͥmo noctẽ gloria suce
resurrectionis illustrauit; et sic diẽ sé discipulis ostendendo consecrauit.
Quos &tiã uesꝑa ꝓcedente conuescendo et se palpandũ os,endo sp̃s q̃q scĩ

div.ab: gatiã tribuendo pleniꝰ suæ resurrectionis fide confirmauit. Et ꝗ tc̃ pͭ
creatã lucẽ factũ .ẽ. uesꝑe & mane dies unꝰ. Nc̃ at̃ uesꝑa sabati lucescit
div.gloss: .i. mane diei dominicæ ut sit unus dies ⁊ nox
div.ab: ĩ pͥma sabati. Ipsa mutatio tẽporis nos q͠q aparadisi quondã lumine trans
latos ĩconuallẽ lacrimarũ iã modo á peccatorũ tenebris adceleste gaudiũ
transferendos e͠e designat.- Neque enĩ alit̃ quã nocte diei p̃posita potest
explicari. ꝙ dñs ĩ exẽplũ ionæ tres dies et noctes ĩ corde terrȩ fuerit. ubi
sinecdochicos sidiẽi paresceues partẽ qua sepultus ÷ cũ p̃tita nocte ꝓnocto
in ui. sabati
et die accipies; hoc ÷ ꝓ toto die sabati noctem et diẽ ĩ tegrũ. et noctẽ dominicã
cũ eodẽ ĩ lucescente.- ác ꝑ hoc ĩcipiente partẽ ꝓ toto habes ꝓfecto triduũ et
tres noctes; Merito aut̃ querit᷑. q͠re populus isrł qͥ diei ordinẽ iuxta moysi tra
ditionẽ ámane semꝑ usq; admane ser,bat festa tam̃ om̃ã sua sic̃ et nos hodie
